document.text: years Abbitt said, Charlie Moses was thé number one man in our area for a number of years. He was a hard fighter for the rural people in the halls of the General Assembly. After ten years of service to the town of Appomattox as council member, Moses was first elected to the senate in 1935. Moses never faced op position in the years to come and continued to serve his con stituents capably and faithfully until his death in 1964. Godwin, not only a close political friend but related to Moses in that the late Mrs. Moses was Godwins aunt said, He was- a truly exceptional man. He had unlimited energy in the pursuit of those things that he felt were best for his country. Godwin praised the late Senator Moses for his Christian devotion to his family, his chur ch and community. Dr. S. R. Lawson, chairman  of the Board of Supervisors for Appomattox County, in accep ting the portrait for the county said, Appomattox is a better place in which to live because of the contributions of Senator Moses.

document.text: Wshipigton.r Representative W. M. Abbitt has sharply criticized the foreign aid program as a give away, welfare, luxury program to be supported by the overburdened and oppressed taxpayers of Amer ica. The Fourth District Congressman told the House of Representatives in a speech late Friday that the program is based on the theory that friendship can be purchased, and pointed out that this philoso phy has not been borne out in the past and I am sure it will not be borne out by future events. Abbitt spoke before the House voted on the foreign aid authoriza tion bill and was critical of the program both from the standpoint of cost and worth to the security of America. The Virginian said he doubted if there has ever been a program in America which has had as much waste and inefficiency as the for eign aid program. The bill before the House, he said, authorizes expenditure of 3,- 242,333,000, a cut of 375,000,000 under the Senate-approved figure, and l,157i,667,000 under the Pres idents original request. While the reduction is commend able, he said, in my opinion we have not gone far enough in during this program.

document.text: WOODSON MARTIN. Concord, Va., June 3, 1895 Seldom has it been our privilege to attend a more beautiful marriage than that which was consummated at Bethleham M. E. Church, last Wednesday evening, at 9 oclock the contracting parties being Mr. Wal ter B. Woodson, a young and rising merchant of this place, and Miss Minnie, the very attractive daughter of Mrs. Emma Martin, also of this town. Long before the appointed hour the church was crowded with friends and relatives anxious to witness this popular couple united in the holy bonds of wedlock. Promptly at the appointed hour the dnlect and in spiring strains of Tanhausers wed ding mach, under the masterly touch of Mrs. G. Norman Abbitt, proclaimed the entry of the bridal cortege. The order of the atteu dants was as follows Miss Nannie Wharton aud Mr Eddie Franklin Miss Sallie Ariing- on and Mr. Miles Shipman Miss Della Steele and Mr. Thesis Lindsay Miss Ruby Woodson and Mr. Rees Evans Miss Ada Staples and Mr. J. L Woodson Miss Evie Martin and Mr. Courtney Thomas Miss Jnlia Woodson and Mr. Edwin Franklin Miss Marie L. Ould and Mr. W.C. Tanner Miss Lula Conch and Mr. Orville Van B. Thompson The pretty little flower bearers enter ed in the following order Miss Katie Carson and Pearl Woodson Miss Jessie Martin and Evelyn Moore Miss Nellie Abbott, Gracie Cross and Johnie Martin. Then appeared the pretty ank blushing bride-elect, with beauti-e ful bouquet of rare spring flowers leaning on the arm of her maid of honor, Miss Florrie Arrington, who were met in front of the chan cel by Mr. Woodson with his best man, Mr. Jno. G. Fisher. There beneath a beautiful arch aud pendent bell of evergreens and spring flowers, this young couple was joined in the bonds of matri mony, bj the Rev. Mr. Parish,of the Methodist church. The wedding party, preceded by the ushers Messrs, W. L. Peet and R. L. Staples with a large number of invited guests re paired immediately to the hospitable home of Mrs. Victoria and Ann E Arrington where a sumptuous dinner awaited them. The happy couple departed Thurs day morning at 120 on the Norfolk and Western east-bound train for Richmond and other points of inter est, accompanied by the well wishes of a large circle of friends. Q u id N u n c .

document.text: WON SPELLING MATCH Miss Peyton Abbitt won first place in the finals of the Appomat tox school spelling match here last week. Peyton is a fifth grader. Miss Margaret Deaner won sec ond place. She is in the eighth grade. These two young girls will com pete tonight in the division spelling match for Appomattox county pub lic schools, which will be held in the auditorium at 730. The winner and the runner - up In tonights match will represent this county in an area spelling bee to be held in Lynchburg.

document.text: Womens Missionary Society of liberty Baptist Church The Women Missionary Society of Liberty Baptist Church, or rather known first as the Ladie  Aid Society, was organized by Rev. Dr Henry W. Tribble in the year of his pastorate of this church, in 18 85. It was a small and feeble beginning but an earnest Christian spirit and effort tup ported the movement of this struggling band of Christian workers. Dr. Tribble even in vited the men to join the society so as to encourage and help the ladies in their Christian work Miss Sue Sears was elected president for several years, and she was active and efficient in the society, as in all other church work, wherever her consecrated life found work for the Heavenly Father Miss Sears best endeavors for His cause were always given I remember a few of the orig inal members Mrs. William H Gills, Mrs. William H. Abbitt Mrs. Joel Oawthorn, Mrs. T. A Caldwell, Mrs. C. W. Hancock Misses Sis OConner, Sis Ab bitt, and Lula Jones. This society met in the Amen corn er of the chnrch for years, after the regular monthly service on the 3rd Sunday of each month This society did much church work in individual ways, but rarely ever had any money, ex cept a few cents in the treasury. We tried lawn parties, lectures, oyster suppers, tableaux, etc. But rains, illness, or something seemed to break us up, minus of finances. If we raised fire or ten dollars a year for our society we thought we had done well, aa in those days ladies Ad minis- were not supposed to have any

Mrs. Watkins Abbitt of Appomattox, wife of the Fourth District Congressman and State Central Committee Chairman, is shown above at the head table with Mrs. John Garland Pollard, of Richmond, National Committeewoman. Also present was Mrs. Calvin Robinson, of Appomattox, al ternate delegate-at-large. The luncheon was held at historic Smithville Inn, in Absecon, New Jersey.

document.text: Womans Club Lists Opening Fall Meeting o The first meeting of the Appo mattox Womans Club for the 1955- 1956 season will be held Monday, September 12 at 300 p. m. in the Appomattox High School Cafeteria. Hostesses for the meeting will be Mrs. G. F. Abbitt, Jr., Mrs. H. C. Pulliam, Mrs. J. D. McDeamon and Mrs. H. Y. Spencer. The program for the meeting is designed to acquaint both new mem bers and old with the scope of Womans Club work. The chairmen of the departments will discuss the work of their departments. These include Mrs. F. F. Carr, Chairmen of the American Home Department Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Chairman of Educa tion and International Affairs Mrs. J. R. Lawson, Chairman of Public Affairs and Legislation Mrs. Mil dred Alvis, Chairman of the Welfare Department and Mrs. Roger Nor fleet, Chairman of Fine Arts.  Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Vice-president of the Alice Kyle District of the Vir ginia Federation of Womans Clubs, will discuss the work of Womans Clubs on a district and state level and Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley will talk about the General Federation of Womans Clubs, which has a total membership of eleven million women. A coffee hour at 300 oclock will precede the business meeting which starts at 330.

document.text: with Miss Mary Elizabeth Paris Mr. William Price with Miss Lucy Smith Mr. Tom Steele with Miss Maude Gregory. The ushers were Messrs. John Rolfe Horsley, B. Watkins Nowlin, John Overton and lampton Steele. The little ribbon- bearers were Jerry Burxe and Jao- queline Atwood Curtis Taylor and Fraces Abbitt Kendall Huuter and Katie Woolridge, and James Stanley and Mattie Sears. Before thp bridal party entered one verse of O Promise Me was softly-sung by Miss Eula Burke ac companied by Mrs. J. R. Atwood. At the conclusion of the solo follow ed the strains of Lohengrins wedding march. The bridesmaids entered from the left wing of tbe church near the altar and passed in front of the altar and down the right aisle. The male attendants entered the left aisle at the front of the church and marched down the right aisle while the bridesmaids passed up the left, forming a semi-circle around the al tar. Following the attendants the groom on the arm of the best man en tered the right aiale, while the bride on the arm of her father, Mr. H. F, Burke, appeared in the left aisle, and proceeded to the alter. The bride was preceded by the maid of honor and followed by her colored maid, Sarah. The bride was attired in a hand some traveling dress of broad-cloth with hat and gloves to matcl. She carried in her hand a small white bible and a white rose-bud. The maid of honor wore a gown of cream crepe cloth, with trimmings of pearls and chiffon, and carried in her hand a large bunch of white chrysanthemums. Tfie bridesmaids wore dresses of white silk mull wearing aigrettes in their hair, and each carrying a white rose iu her hand. After lunching at the brides home they happy pair left on the 130 oclock train for a tour through the West, followed by the best wishes of a host of friends. The groom is a son of Mr. John Steel, of Concord, and bolds the re sponsible position of Agent at Spout Springs of tbe N.  W. By., and is a young man highly esteemed and very popular wherever known. He  has for his young bride a daughter I of Mr. B. F. Burke, cashier of our bank. She is attractive popular, j and highly accomplished. She is  an expert at the telegraph key and Mr. Steele will have a help mate ca pable as be. The presents were  costly and beautiful.

document.text: With membership reports indica ting a nice attendance, the Young Democratic Club of Appomattox co unty is all set for its second annual Brunswick Stew, to be held at 4 P. M. tomorrow, Friday, August 23, at Holiday Lake. Senator William, M. Tuck, of Halifax, a prospective candidate for Governor next year, will be speaker. A number of prominent Democrats from neighboring counties have been invited to attend. An expert in the art of making 1 Brunswick Stew, from Charlotte co-  unty, has been engaged and will be on the job early tomorrow morning. President Watt Abbitt said he ex pected to have a membership this year of between 150 and 200.irhe annual dues of the club are 1.00, and entitle one to attend the Bruns wick Stew without extra charge. Tickets may be secured from any member of a large membership com mittee, and will be available at the lake tomorrow afternoon. The Young Democratic Clubs are composed of younger members of the party and serve as a traing ground for future leaders. The organiza tion was highly honored Tuesday in R.chmond, when one of iis number, Horace Edwards, of Richmond, was chosen chairman of the State Senior Democratic Committee, to succeed the late Murray Hooker. The Sta.e Young Democratic con vention will be held in Richmond on September 6 and 7. A regular meet ing of the local club will be held tomorrow after the speaking. Funeral oí Mrs. arson

document.text: With many visitors, friends and members of the St. Luke Church, services there were well attended. Rev. McLaugh lin was in charge. Rev. Alvin Jones assisted him. The Adult Choir gave very - inspiring music. Rev. McLaughlin spoke from 2nd Timothy 1-12, subjecGFully Secured. He brought out that our only security is in God. This was well taken. The offering was good. A special prayer was offered for the ill ones of the community by Rev. Jones. Namely Mr. Henry Hamlette, Mr. Bolin Jones, Mrs. Edith Jones, Miss Samatha Marshall, Mrs. Esther Callaham, Mr. Collins Callaham, and Mrs. Ocie Elliott, who will enter the hospital today, Mon. for treatm ent. Also , we are concerned about a much respected friend of the St. Lukers, the Rév. R. Q. Lawing and Mrs. Willie Mae McLaugh lin. On Jan. 30 the Senior Citizens of St. Luke who do volunteer work at the Lynch burg Home and Hospital attended a surprise birthday party for Mrs. Lena Wood, who was 87 years old. She was so graceously surprised and so calmly accepted the -kindness she received a beautiful corsage and gifts from the staff and was recognized as the Sweetheart Of The Day.  The news staff took T.V. pictures of the occasion. It was shown on the 600 p.m. news and also the 1100 oclock news. Those on the screen were Mrs. Virginia Abbitt, Mrs. Louise Canada and others shown doing friendly acts for the patients. The Senior Citizens of - St. Luke really enjoy going up each Friday and doing volunteer work for. those patients, The St. Lukes Senior Choir will be observing its aimiver- sary Feb. 22. All are invited to attend. Churches are being invited. Please come and enjoy this musical program. The Maggie Claytor Senior Club will meet at the home of Mrs. Evatna Prophett Feb. 9. All are so thankful for the refreshing rain.  Jordan Baptist news

W illiams School of Law of the U niversity of Rich mond, graduating with honors in 1965. He has completed a tour of duty with theU.S. Army, s e r  ving as Captain with the Judge Advocate G enerals Corps. For the past three years he has been associated with the firm of McGuire, Wood and Bat tle in Richmond, me of the la r  gest legal firm s in Virginia.  Sam as he is affectionate ly called, is m arried to the form er Ann Abbitt, of Appomat tox and they have two daughters, Anne Leight, 3, and Amy, one and one-half y ears old.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox. document.text: William C. Hubbard, chairman of the Appomattox Civil War Centennial Committee and Mrs. Carrie Gilbert, chairman of the Official Program subcommittee, have made public details of the official program for commemo ration of the 100th anniversary of the Surrender at Appomattox. The afternoons events begin at Appomattox Court House Na tional Historical Park at 140 p.m. with a band concert by the United States Marine Band from Quantico, Virginia. Master of ceremonies for the program to follow at 200 p.m. will be the Honorable John War ren Cooke, chairman, executive committee of the Virginia Civil War Commission. Virginia Military Institute will present colors. An official wel come will be delivered by Gov ernor Albertis S. Harrison, Jr., with the Honorable John War ren Cooke introducing dis tinguished guests. William M. McMillan, Assist ant Postmaster General, will present a Commemorative Stamp Album. Elbert Cox, Regional Direc tor, National Park Service, will introduce Bruce Catton, m a i n speaker for the occasion. A rib bon cutting for the reconstruct ed Court House will follow the 2 p.m. program with Major Gen eral Ulysses S. Grant, HI, and honored guests. Music of Blue and Gray The Appomattox Civic Cho rus is presenting Music of the Blue and Gray on Friday eve ning, April 9, at Appomattox High School. No tickets are be ing sold, but a silver offering will be taken at the door. UDC-American Legion On Saturday, April 10, at 8 p.m. the United Daughters of the Confederacy, American Legion and Legion Auxiliary, will pre sent, a memorial program at the AppqoKUtoElementary School. Em f. otwppomattog map went w a in this county to  SérvW  1 the Abbitt F l o o d , M athew sand Robertson com panies. Names of these men will be read, and thefe will be special solos and band music, according to current plans. Peace Service On Sunday, April 11, at 3 p.m. the Appomattox Ministerial As sociation and the Appomattox County Civil War Centennial Committee will present a Peace Service at Appomattox Court House National Historial Park. Speaker will be the Reverend Walker Bocock Healy, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Roanoke, and a great grand son of the first clerk of Appo mattox County. Official programs describing these events will be on sale.
